questions.text:
A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath that began while playing outdoors with his grandson. He has a history of asthma but does not take any medications for it. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. He is out of breath and unable to finish his sentences. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 23/min and labored, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nasal flaring and sternocleidomastoid muscle use. Pulmonary examination shows poor air movement bilaterally and no wheezing. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Oxygen is administered via a nonrebreather mask. He is given three doses of nebulized albuterol, inhaled ipratropium, and intravenous methylprednisolone. After 1 hour, the patient is confused and disoriented. Arterial blood gas analysis shows:


pH
7.34


Pco2
46 mm Hg


Po2
54 mm Hg


O2 saturation
87%


Assessing peak expiratory flow rate is not possible because the patient is unable to carry out the test due to shortness of breath. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient initially presented with a severe asthma exacerbation (difficulty speaking, accessory muscle use, labored breathing) that became life-threatening despite adequate medical treatment. He now presents with signs of imminent respiratory arrest, which warrants endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation. Treatment of severe to life-threatening asthma exacerbations includes oxygen therapy, nebulized SAMA and SABA, and systemic glucocorticoids. IV magnesium sulfate and inhaled glucocorticoid therapy can also be considered.

Most patients with acute asthma exacerbation initially present with respiratory alkalosis due to tachypnea. With worsening airway obstruction and increasing respiratory fatigue, Pco2 increases while pH decreases. Poor air movement combined with the absence of wheezing in this patient is also consistent with severe airway obstruction: wheezing is not heard because there is not enough air movement to generate it.
Image Description:

BP: blood pressure
HR: heart rate
ICS: inhaled corticosteroid
ICU: intensive care unit
IV: intravenous
O2: oxygen
PEF: peak expiratory flow
PO: per os
RR: respiratory rate
SABA: short-acting beta agonist
SAMA: short-acting muscarinic antagonist
SpO2: oxygen saturation

B) INCORRECT:

Theophylline is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor with antiinflammatory and bronchodilatory effects that can be used in maintenance therapy for COPD if no other bronchodilators are available. Theophylline is no longer routinely used in asthma because of its adverse cardiotoxic and neurotoxic effects.

C) INCORRECT:

Continuous albuterol nebulizer therapy can be used in patients with acute asthma exacerbation under specialist guidance, but there is insufficient data to recommend its routine use. Additionally, this patient has not responded to three doses of nebulized albuterol and now presents with signs of impending respiratory failure. Another step in management is more appropriate at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic therapy is often used in the treatment of acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease but is not routinely recommended in patients with acute asthma exacerbation without signs of infection (e.g., pneumonia).

E) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular epinephrine therapy is appropriate for patients with anaphylaxis, which can also cause dyspnea due to upper airway edema and bronchospasm. However, anaphylaxis is usually associated with other systemic symptoms such as urticaria, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, and/or angioedema. Epinephrine injections are not indicated for acute asthma exacerbation.
questions.hint: Silent chest, altered mental status, hypercapnia, and hypoxia suggest life-threatening asthma exacerbation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother for worsening wheezing and shortness of breath over the past day. He has not had a fever, cough, vomiting, or diarrhea. He has asthma and eczema. He uses a glucocorticoid inhaler and an albuterol inhaler but has missed his medications for the past week while on vacation. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Expiratory and inspiratory wheezing is heard throughout both lung fields. There are moderate intercostal and subcostal retractions and a decreased inspiratory to expiratory ratio. Nebulized albuterol and ipratropium treatments and intravenous methylprednisolone are given in the emergency department for a presumed asthma exacerbation. One hour later, the child is limp and lethargic. Magnesium sulfate is administered. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. No wheezing is heard on repeat pulmonary examination. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Add leukotriene-receptor antagonists to nebulizer treatment
Add racemic epinephrine to nebulizer treatment
Perform needle thoracostomy at the 2nd intercostal space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leukotriene-receptor antagonists, such as montelukast, have not been shown to improve respiratory outcomes in pediatric patients presenting to the emergency department with acute asthma exacerbations.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has likely become hypercapnic from poor ventilation, resulting in altered mental status (lethargy) and inability to protect his airway. He requires intubation with mechanical ventilation to prevent respiratory arrest and/or hypoxic insult. Intubation should not be delayed for additional pharmacologic therapies.
Image Description:

BP: blood pressure
HR: heart rate
ICS: inhaled corticosteroid
ICU: intensive care unit
IV: intravenous
O2: oxygen
PEF: peak expiratory flow
PO: per os
RR: respiratory rate
SABA: short-acting beta agonist
SAMA: short-acting muscarinic antagonist
SpO2: oxygen saturation

C) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine is indicated for anaphylaxis, which can manifest with dyspnea, tachypnea, and wheezing. However, this patient does not have other typical features of anaphylaxis (e.g., sudden-onset flushing, urticaria, hypotension). Racemic epinephrine is also used in the management of croup, but this patient does not have consistent symptoms (e.g., barking cough, rhinorrhea, cough, fever). Epinephrine is not part of the standard treatment for severe asthma exacerbation.

D) INCORRECT:

Needle thoracostomy at the 2nd intercostal space is used for the treatment of tension pneumothorax. Although this patient has decreased breath sounds, they are decreased bilaterally with wheezing, making bronchoconstriction (secondary to status asthmaticus) a more likely cause of respiratory failure than a pneumothorax.

E) INCORRECT:

Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation can avoid the need for endotracheal intubation by providing respiratory support while waiting for pharmacotherapies to take full effect. However, intact mental status is required for the use of noninvasive positive pressure ventilation, as patients must be able to protect their airways to reduce the risk of aspiration. This patient's declining mental status (lethargic and limp) precludes the use of noninvasive positive pressure ventilation.

F) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy can be both diagnostic and therapeutic for children with foreign body aspiration, which can present as respiratory distress, as seen here. However, foreign body aspiration usually presents with the sudden onset of stridor in young children (< 3 years of age). Because this 6-year-old patient has a history of asthma along with worsening bilateral wheezing over the course of a day, status asthmaticus is a more likely cause of his respiratory distress.

G) INCORRECT:

There is little evidence to suggest that levalbuterol is superior to racemic albuterol in acute asthma exacerbations. Also, levalbuterol is significantly more expensive. More importantly, this patient has worsening respiratory failure despite albuterol nebulizers and therefore requires a higher level of treatment.

H) INCORRECT:

Although not part of most standard asthma protocols, heliox can be administered along with beta-agonists in patients with severe asthma exacerbations to improve laminar flow. However, this patient has impending respiratory arrest and requires a different step in management.

I) INCORRECT:

This patient will require at least 3 days of systemic glucocorticoids to reduce airway inflammation from his asthma exacerbation. However, methylprednisolone will take 2–4 hours for maximal effect. This patient has impending respiratory arrest that requires immediate management.
questions.hint: This patient has status asthmaticus, a type of severe asthma exacerbation. Despite initial treatment, he has a decline in mental status, decreased wheezing (due to poor aeration), and decreased respiratory rate (due to fatigue from increased work of breathing), which together are concerning for impending respiratory arrest.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of progressive shortness of breath and chest tightness for 3 hours. She has had an intermittent nonproductive cough for the past two months. Her 16-year old son had an upper respiratory infection last week and was treated with azithromycin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years but stopped smoking 5 years ago. She works at a cattle ranch. She appears anxious and is unable to speak in full sentences. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5 F), pulse is 100/min, her blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, and respirations are 28/min. A chest x-ray is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?



Chest excursion
Breath sounds
Chest percussion
Tactile fremitus



A
asymmetric
decreased
dull
decreased


B
asymmetric
absent
hyperresonant
decreased


C
symmetric
basal crackles
dull
increased


D
asymmetric
basal crackles
dull
increased


E
symmetric
decreased
hyperresonant
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These findings are consistent with pleural effusion. When fluid infiltrates the pleural space it insulates sounds originating from the lung parenchyma, which results in a decrease in both breath sounds and tactile fremitus. Cough and dyspnea may be seen in pleural effusion, but there is no evidence of an effusion on this patient's chest x-ray.

B) INCORRECT:

These findings are consistent with pneumothorax. In this condition, the air in the pleural space leads to hyperresonant percussion and decreased tactile fremitus on the affected side. Pneumothorax should always be considered in patients with new-onset shortness of breath. However, there is no evidence of pneumothorax on this patient's chest x-ray.

C) INCORRECT:

These findings are consistent with pulmonary fibrosis. Patients with pulmonary fibrosis often have basal crackles on auscultation and can present with normal or increased tactile fremitus. Pulmonary fibrosis can manifest with dyspnea and a nonproductive cough, and it may be caused by farmer's lung, which this patient's occupation is a risk factor for. However, pulmonary fibrosis typically has a more chronic and progressive course than what is seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

These clinical exam findings are consistent with a consolidative process, such as lobar pneumonia. While pneumonia can also present with dyspnea, this patient lacks other symptoms of pneumonia, such as productive cough, fever, malaise, and/or chills. Furthermore, her chest x-ray does not have evidence of consolidation.

E) CORRECT:

Decreased breath sounds, hyperresonant percussion, and decreased tactile fremitus are consistent with pulmonary hyperinflation, which in this case is secondary to the patient's severe asthma exacerbation. Wheezing is another typical finding in asthma exacerbation but can be absent in very severe cases.

Based on her history, this patient likely has nonallergic asthma, which often manifests later in life and is associated with smoking exposure.
questions.hint: Chest x-ray shows parenchymal lucency, a low, flattened diaphragm, and wide intercostal spaces, all of which are signs of pulmonary hyperinflation. These findings, combined with the patient's history and clinical findings, are concerning for a severe asthma exacerbation.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of severe shortness of breath and dry cough for 30 minutes. The symptoms started while she participated in a soccer tournament at her school. Her father was diagnosed with asthma as a child. Her pulse is 130/min and respirations are 35/min. Treatment with inhaled albuterol is initiated. A physician administers a second drug to increase the action of albuterol on bronchial smooth muscle cell receptors. Which of the following drugs is most likely to have had this effect?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous magnesium sulfate increases smooth muscle dilation in intermediate and small airways. This drug is indicated for patients with a life-threatening asthma exacerbation, as seen here, to reduce the severity of respiratory distress. However, it does not demonstrate a permissive effect on albuterol.

B) CORRECT:

Steroids (e.g., prednisolone, dexamethasone) demonstrate a permissive drug interaction with adrenergic receptor agonists (e.g., albuterol), thereby increasing the amplitude of the maximal response to adrenergic agonists. Steroids accomplish this by increasing adrenergic receptor activation and the concentration of signaling intermediates (e.g., cyclic AMP). They demonstrate a dose-dependent response, meaning that the amplitude of the maximal activation increases as the steroid concentration increases. Systemic steroids are therefore often used in patients with severe asthma exacerbations to increase the therapeutic effect of albuterol on respiratory distress. They are also used to increase the potency of adrenergic agonists in patients with anaphylaxis or severe shock.

C) INCORRECT:

Theophylline inhibits phosphodiesterase; it primarily has an antiinflammatory effect, and to a lesser extent it facilitates bronchodilation. It was previously used as adjuvant therapy to prevent asthma exacerbations, but is no longer routinely used due to side effects. In addition, theophylline does not have a permissive effect on albuterol.

D) INCORRECT:

Cromolyn sodium prevents mast cells from releasing inflammatory mediators that stimulate bronchoconstriction. It was previously used as a preventive treatment in patients with asthma prior to exercise or unavoidable exposure to known allergens, but it is no longer recommended. In addition, it does not have a permissive effect on albuterol, and it is not administered in acute asthma exacerbations.

E) INCORRECT:

Montelukast noncompetitively inhibits leukotriene receptors (CysLT1) and thereby reduces bronchoconstriction and airway inflammation. This drug is prescribed as an alternative long-term treatment option for exercise-induced asthma and aspirin-induced asthma. It does not have a permissive effect on albuterol, and it is not administered in acute asthma exacerbations.

F) INCORRECT:

Aerosolized ipratropium bromide is indicated for patients with a severe asthma exacerbation, which this patient has, to reduce the severity of respiratory distress. Ipratropium bromide competitively inhibits postganglionic muscarinic receptors in bronchial smooth muscles, thereby facilitating the dilation of intermediate and small airways. However, it does not have a permissive effect on albuterol.
questions.hint: The second drug is required for albuterol to exert its full effect on its target receptor, a phenomenon called permissiveness.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man with a history of severe, persistent asthma is admitted to the intensive care unit in respiratory distress. He is sitting upright with marked accessory-muscle use.
Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 150/80 mm Hg, a heart rate of 120 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and a peripheral oxygen saturation of 86% on 2 liters of oxygen. Pulmonary examination reveals prominent bilateral expiratory wheezes. Except for the tachycardia, the rest of the patient’s examination is unremarkable.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Arterial blood gas readings show a pH of 7.31 (reference range, 7.38–7.44), partial pressure of carbon dioxide 50 mm Hg (35–45), and partial pressure of oxygen 96 mm Hg (80–100).
The patient receives intravenous glucocorticoids and continuous nebulized albuterol. He becomes confused with increasing respiratory distress and is intubated for progressive respiratory failure. He is placed on volume control with a tidal volume of 600 mL and a frequency of 24 per minute; positive end-expiratory pressure 10 cm of water; and 100% fraction of inspired oxygen.
Thirty minutes after intubation, he has a blood pressure of 80/30 mm Hg, a heart rate of 145 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and a peripheral oxygen saturation of 99% on 100% fraction of inspired oxygen.
Breath sounds are diminished bilaterally. Peak inspiratory pressures are 45–50 mm Hg.
A ventilator-flow waveform is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following actions is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Disconnect the patient’s endotracheal tube from the ventilator
Administer a 2-liter bolus of normal saline
Increase positive end-expiratory pressure to 15 mm Hg

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with severe obstructive lung disease, such as severe asthma, it is critical to maximize expiratory time to prevent the development of intrinsic positive end-expiratory pressure (auto-PEEP). The resulting hyperinflation and increased intrathoracic pressure can result in devastating cardiovascular collapse. The quickest way to detect this physiology is by examining the ventilator-flow waveform. Auto-PEEP is visualized as the failure of the expiratory flow to reach zero before delivery of the next inspiratory breath. Immediate detachment of the ventilator from the endotracheal tube relieves the hyperinflated lungs and improves hemodynamics.

Key learning point: Intrinsic positive end-expiratory pressure is a risk of mechanical ventilation in patients with asthma and can be managed by disconnecting the patient’s endotracheal tube from the ventilator.

B) INCORRECT:

Vasopressors and fluids are unlikely to provide timely relief of hemodynamic compromise.

C) INCORRECT:

Although a patient in this condition is at increased risk for barotrauma, placing a chest tube would not be appropriate without evidence of a pneumothorax.

D) INCORRECT:

Vasopressors and fluids are unlikely to provide timely relief of hemodynamic compromise.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased PEEP would not help and could worsen the patient’s hemodynamic instability.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman with a history of asthma, type 2 diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity presents to the emergency department reporting shortness of breath and chest pain for the past 2 days. She describes the pain as a nonradiating pressure over the center of her chest that she has never experienced before. She has been using her albuterol inhaler every hour to relieve the shortness of breath, with minimal success. She reports no increase in sputum production. She works at a day-care center and has been in contact with several sick children recently. Her current medications are fluticasone-salmeterol, albuterol, amlodipine, atorvastatin, and metformin.
On physical examination, she has a blood pressure of 120/78 mm Hg, a heart rate of 124 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, an oxygen saturation of 89% while receiving 6 liters of supplemental oxygen, and a BMI of 36. She is currently free of chest pain. Lung examination reveals diffuse wheezing in all lung fields. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia with a regular rhythm and no murmurs. There is no jugular venous distention, lower-extremity edema, or clubbing.
A chest radiograph shows no acute process. An electrocardiogram reveals T-wave inversions with 2-mm ST depressions in leads II, III, and aVF. A complete blood count and chemistry are normal. The troponin-T level (measured using a 4th-generation assay) is 1.2 ng/mL (reference range, 0–0.03), and the brain natriuretic peptide level is 30 pg/mL (≤84).
Oxygen and aspirin therapy are initiated. Atorvastatin is continued.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Nebulized albuterol, oral prednisone, and oral beta-blocker
Nebulized levalbuterol, nebulized ipratropium, and nebulized budesonide

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with both an acute asthma exacerbation and non-ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) with evidence of ischemia. Her vital signs reveal tachycardia and tachypnea. She requires therapy for both the asthma exacerbation and the NSTEMI, with careful monitoring for therapeutic effect and potential medication-related adverse effects.

Although this patient’s tachycardia is worrisome, several factors are likely to be contributing, including the hourly use of nebulized albuterol before presentation and the underlying airflow obstruction and increased work of breathing. There is a potential concern that continued use of a short-acting beta-agonist could worsen the tachycardia, an undesirable effect in the setting of known cardiac ischemia, but definitive therapy for the known asthma exacerbation should take priority in initial management decisions.

Appropriate management of this patient’s asthma should include nebulized albuterol-ipratropium and a systemic glucocorticoid, such as methylprednisolone. Current guidelines recommend using the short-acting bronchodilators albuterol and ipratropium together in the setting of a severe acute exacerbation (rather than either agent alone) for maximal benefit.

The combination of methylprednisolone and nebulized budesonide would be inappropriate for this patient, who needs bronchodilator therapy as well as systemic glucocorticoids.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for an asthma exacerbation in a patient presenting with a concurrent non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction is nebulized albuterol-ipratropium and a systemic glucocorticoid, with close monitoring of hemodynamic parameters.

B) INCORRECT:

Appropriate management of this patient’s asthma should include nebulized albuterol-ipratropium and a systemic glucocorticoid, such as methylprednisolone.

C) INCORRECT:

Appropriate management for an NSTEMI typically includes supplemental oxygen, a beta-blocker, aspirin, and continuation of the patient’s home statin. However, caution should be used initiating beta-blockers in the setting of a severe acute exacerbation of obstructive lung disease. Joint guidelines from the American Heart Association and the American College of Cardiology recommend initiating oral beta-blocker use within the first 24 hours of NSTEMI presentation unless the patient has contraindications such as an active asthma exacerbation, which is the case here. Patients who are not considered candidates for beta-blocker use in the first 24 hours should be reevaluated for eligibility after clinical improvement.

D) INCORRECT:

A systemic glucocorticoid such as methylprednisolone or prednisone is preferable to a nebulized glucocorticoid such as budesonide.

E) INCORRECT:

Levalbuterol has been suggested as an alternative agent to albuterol in the setting of tachycardia, but currently available literature does not suggest a clinically significant difference in the heart-rate effect of these two medications. A systemic glucocorticoid such as methylprednisolone or prednisone is preferable to a nebulized glucocorticoid such as budesonide.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man with a history of asthma presents to the emergency department with pleuritic chest pain and a one-day history of dyspnea, cough, and wheezing not responsive to home albuterol. His asthma is normally well controlled with daily inhaled fluticasone-salmeterol, and he usually requires inhaled albuterol only one to two times per week. He has previously been hospitalized for asthma exacerbations but has never been intubated. He has not experienced any nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain. A family member has had cough and nasal congestion for the past 4 days.
The patient appears to be in respiratory distress. His initial vital signs include a heart rate of 110 beats per minute with a regular rhythm, a respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 135/82 mm Hg, a temperature of 37.0°C, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while he is breathing ambient air. Cardiac examination is notable for a crunching noise during systole. Pulmonary examination reveals use of accessory respiratory muscles and poor air movement throughout the lung fields. Crepitus is evident with palpation over the upper chest in the midline. Abdominal examination is unremarkable.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Initial laboratory evaluation, including a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel, is unremarkable. Arterial blood gas testing shows a pH of 7.50 (reference range, 7.38 –7.44), partial pressure of oxygen of 115 mm Hg (80–100), partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 25 mm Hg (35–45), and a bicarbonate level of 21 mEq/liter (21–30).
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

choices.text: Bilateral chest-tube thoracostomy with connection to suction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NPPV) is commonly used to support patients with exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease but is rarely used in the treatment of severe asthma exacerbations. In addition, this patient has not yet received bronchodilators or glucocorticoids and may respond to these less-invasive treatments first. Another concern is that the positive pressure of NPPV may worsen the pneumomediastinum, potentially but rarely leading to tension pneumomediastinum. If NPPV were started or this patient were intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation, serial imaging would be required to monitor the pneumomediastinum. Although the degree of respiratory distress in this patient may prompt the clinician to consider NPPV, the arterial blood gas remains appropriately compensated with a respiratory alkalosis and normoxia. Careful observation is warranted, and the patient should be reassessed after therapy is initiated targeting the cause of the respiratory distress; if the patient does not improve, the risk-to-benefit ratio of intubation with mechanical ventilation should be carefully evaluated.

B) INCORRECT:

Pneumomediastinum is generally the result of distal alveolar rupture and not central airway defects that can be visualized on bronchoscopy. More important, performing bronchoscopy on this patient without first managing the asthma exacerbation could lead to worsening bronchospasm and respiratory failure.

C) INCORRECT:

In rare cases, pneumomediastinum may be accompanied by pneumothorax, which should be managed similarly to any secondary pneumothorax. If a pneumothorax is causing tension physiology by compressing structures in the chest, needle thoracostomy can be performed to evacuate air from the pleural space; chest-tube thoracostomy can be performed either after needle decompression or without needle decompression if there is no tension physiology. In this patient, there is pneumomediastinum but no evidence of pneumothorax; air has collected in the mediastinal space, and it is not removable with needle thoracostomy or chest-tube placement.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has pneumomediastinum complicating a severe asthma exacerbation. In patients with asthma, pneumomediastinum is caused by rupture of alveoli in the setting of small-airway obstruction, followed by movement of free air along the airways and vasculature to the mediastinum by dissection through the supporting soft tissue.

The normal presenting symptoms of pneumomediastinum are similar to those of an asthma exacerbation, including dyspnea, cough, and wheezing. Other symptoms may include pain in the neck, throat, and chest. Subcutaneous emphysema may be appreciated over the neck and chest — and may lead to the characteristic physical examination finding of crunching sounds auscultated over the precordium that are synchronous with the heartbeat (the Hamman sign).

On this radiograph, the mediastinal pleura is separated from the mediastinum and becomes visible as a thin white line, indicated by the white arrows. Pneumomediastinum is normally a benign, self-limited condition that requires no intervention. In this patient, initial management should focus on treating the asthma exacerbation, including inhaled bronchodilators and systemic glucocorticoids.

In rare cases, pneumomediastinum may be accompanied by pneumothorax, which should be managed similarly to any secondary pneumothorax. If a pneumothorax is causing tension physiology by compressing structures in the chest, needle thoracostomy can be performed to evacuate air from the pleural space; chest-tube thoracostomy can be performed either after needle decompression or without needle decompression if there is no tension physiology. In this patient, there is pneumomediastinum but no evidence of pneumothorax; air has collected in the mediastinal space, and it is not removable with needle thoracostomy or chest-tube placement.

Even more rarely, pneumomediastinum may lead to tension physiology, causing compression of the airway, heart, and vascular structures in the mediastinum and potentially leading to respiratory or hemodynamic compromise. Tension pneumomediastinum should be managed with mediastinoscopy to evacuate the free air that is causing compression.

Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NPPV) is commonly used to support patients with exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease but is rarely used in the treatment of severe asthma exacerbations. In addition, this patient has not yet received bronchodilators or glucocorticoids and may respond to these less-invasive treatments first. Another concern is that the positive pressure of NPPV may worsen the pneumomediastinum, potentially but rarely leading to tension pneumomediastinum. If NPPV were started or this patient were intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation, serial imaging would be required to monitor the pneumomediastinum. Although the degree of respiratory distress in this patient may prompt the clinician to consider NPPV, the arterial blood gas remains appropriately compensated with a respiratory alkalosis and normoxia. Careful observation is warranted, and the patient should be reassessed after therapy is initiated targeting the cause of the respiratory distress; if the patient does not improve, the risk-to-benefit ratio of intubation with mechanical ventilation should be carefully evaluated.

Key learning point: Pneumomediastinum in the setting of an acute asthma exacerbation should be managed with treatment of the asthma exacerbation with inhaled bronchodilators and intravenous glucocorticoids, as well as careful observation of the pneumomediastinum.
Image Description:

Pneumomediastinum in the setting of severe asthma exacerbation

E) INCORRECT:

In rare cases, pneumomediastinum may be accompanied by pneumothorax, which should be managed similarly to any secondary pneumothorax. If a pneumothorax is causing tension physiology by compressing structures in the chest, needle thoracostomy can be performed to evacuate air from the pleural space; chest-tube thoracostomy can be performed either after needle decompression or without needle decompression if there is no tension physiology. In this patient, there is pneumomediastinum but no evidence of pneumothorax; air has collected in the mediastinal space, and it is not removable with needle thoracostomy or chest-tube placement.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy with a history of intermittent asthma and eczema presents to the emergency department (ED). For the past 5 days, he has had a worsening nonproductive cough without rhinorrhea, congestion, or other symptoms of an upper respiratory infection. His mother has noticed suprasternal retractions when he breathes and believes that his symptoms have been triggered by changes in weather. He has previously been prescribed albuterol but has run out of it.
On physical examination, he has a temperature of 38.5°C, a heart rate of 101 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 33 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 103/74 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 90% while breathing ambient air. He appears to be in moderate distress, with subcostal and suprasternal retractions as well as nasal flaring. Respiratory examination is notable for diminished aeration bilaterally, with a few scattered inspiratory and expiratory wheezes, and a prolonged expiratory phase. The rest of the examination is normal.
In addition to methylprednisolone, three back-to-back treatments of nebulized albuterol and ipratropium are administered without a change in oxygen saturation, and the patient is subsequently hospitalized.
Which one of the following features of this patient’s presentation placed him at greatest risk for hospital admission?

choices.text: Cough without other symptoms of an upper respiratory infection
Oxygen saturation <94% one hour after initiation of treatment
Fever at the time of presentation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with acute severe asthma, a history of fever has not been significantly associated with the duration of symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

In patients with acute severe asthma, a history of fever has not been significantly associated with any particular triggers (such as weather changes).

C) INCORRECT:

Currently, there is no gold-standard tool for predicting which patients treated for asthma in the emergency department (ED) will require hospitalization. However, symptoms of an upper respiratory infection on presentation have been shown to correlate with the need for hospitalization, but a cough without other symptoms of an upper respiratory infection has not been specifically mentioned as a predictive factor.

D) CORRECT:

Acute severe asthma (status asthmaticus) is defined as an exacerbation of asthma that does not resolve with repeated doses of beta2-agonist (e.g., albuterol) treatment.

Currently, there is no gold-standard tool for predicting which patients treated for asthma in the emergency department (ED) will require hospitalization. However, there are certain clinical features on presentation that have been shown to correlate with the need for hospitalization, including:

• A pulse-oximetry reading (oxygen saturation) <94% one hour after initiation of treatment
• Symptoms of an upper respiratory infection on presentation
• Worse clinical score at the time of presentation, calculated using physical examination findings such as work of breathing and degree of wheezing

The number of albuterol treatments received in the ED has also been associated with the need for hospitalization; with each subsequent treatment, the likelihood of admission increases.

Key learning point: A strong clinical predictor of admission in a patient with an acute exacerbation of asthma is a pulse-oximetry reading (oxygen saturation) <94% one hour after initiation of treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with acute severe asthma, a history of fever has not been significantly associated with the need for hospitalization.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy with a history of asthma presents to the emergency department with pleuritic chest pain and a one-day history of dyspnea, cough, and wheezing not responsive to home albuterol. His asthma is normally well controlled with daily inhaled fluticasone-salmeterol, and he usually requires inhaled albuterol only one to two times per week. He has previously been hospitalized for asthma exacerbations but has never been intubated. He has not experienced any nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain. A family member has had cough and nasal congestion for the past 4 days.
The patient appears to be in respiratory distress. His initial vital signs include a heart rate of 110 beats per minute with a regular rhythm, a respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 129/82 mm Hg, a temperature of 37.0°C, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while he is breathing ambient air. Cardiac examination is notable for a crunching noise during systole. Pulmonary examination reveals use of accessory respiratory muscles and poor air movement throughout the lung fields. Crepitus is evident with palpation over the upper chest in the midline. Abdominal examination is unremarkable.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Initial laboratory evaluation, including a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel, is unremarkable. Arterial blood gas testing shows a pH of 7.50 (reference range, 7.35 –7.45), partial pressure of oxygen of 115 mm Hg (83–108), partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 25 mm Hg (32–48), and a bicarbonate level of 21 mEq/liter (20–28).
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

choices.text: Bilateral chest-tube thoracostomy with connection to suction

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has pneumomediastinum complicating a severe asthma exacerbation. In patients with asthma, pneumomediastinum is caused by rupture of alveoli in the setting of small-airway obstruction, followed by movement of free air along the airways and vasculature to the mediastinum by dissection through the supporting soft tissue.

The normal presenting symptoms of pneumomediastinum are similar to those of an asthma exacerbation, including dyspnea, cough, and wheezing. Other symptoms may include pain in the neck, throat, and chest. Subcutaneous emphysema may be appreciated over the neck and chest — and may lead to the characteristic physical examination finding of crunching sounds auscultated over the precordium that are synchronous with the heartbeat (the Hamman sign).

This patient’s pneumomediastinum is visible on the chest radiograph: The mediastinal pleura is separated from the mediastinum and becomes visible as a thin white line; this is best seen on the left side below the aortic notch and can also be seen on the right side at the same level.

Pneumomediastinum is normally a benign, self-limited condition that requires no intervention. In this patient, initial management should focus on treating the asthma exacerbation, including inhaled bronchodilators and systemic glucocorticoids.

In rare cases, pneumomediastinum may be accompanied by pneumothorax, which should be managed similarly to any secondary pneumothorax.

Even more rarely, pneumomediastinum may lead to tension physiology, causing compression of the airway, heart, and vascular structures in the mediastinum and potentially leading to respiratory or hemodynamic compromise. Tension pneumomediastinum should be managed with mediastinoscopy to evacuate the free air that is causing compression.

Key learning point: Pneumomediastinum in the setting of an acute asthma exacerbation should be managed with treatment of the asthma exacerbation with inhaled bronchodilators and intravenous glucocorticoids, as well as careful observation of the pneumomediastinum.

B) INCORRECT:

In rare cases, pneumomediastinum may be accompanied by pneumothorax, which should be managed similarly to any secondary pneumothorax. If a pneumothorax is causing tension physiology by compressing structures in the chest, needle thoracostomy can be performed to evacuate air from the pleural space; chest-tube thoracostomy can be performed either after needle decompression or without needle decompression if there is no tension physiology. In this patient, there is pneumomediastinum but no evidence of pneumothorax; air has collected in the mediastinal space, and it is not removable with needle thoracostomy or chest-tube placement.

C) INCORRECT:

In rare cases, pneumomediastinum may be accompanied by pneumothorax, which should be managed similarly to any secondary pneumothorax. If a pneumothorax is causing tension physiology by compressing structures in the chest, needle thoracostomy can be performed to evacuate air from the pleural space; chest-tube thoracostomy can be performed either after needle decompression or without needle decompression if there is no tension physiology. In this patient, there is pneumomediastinum but no evidence of pneumothorax; air has collected in the mediastinal space, and it is not removable with needle thoracostomy or chest-tube placement.

D) INCORRECT:

Pneumomediastinum is generally the result of distal alveolar rupture and not central airway defects that can be visualized on bronchoscopy. More important, performing bronchoscopy on this patient without first managing the asthma exacerbation could lead to worsening bronchospasm and respiratory failure.

E) INCORRECT:

Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NPPV) can be used in the treatment of severe asthma exacerbations. However, this patient has not yet received bronchodilators or glucocorticoids and may respond to these less-invasive treatments first. In addition, the positive pressure of NPPV may worsen the pneumomediastinum, potentially but rarely leading to tension pneumomediastinum. If NPPV were started or this patient were intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation, serial imaging would be required to monitor the pneumomediastinum. Although the degree of respiratory distress in this patient may prompt the clinician to consider NPPV, the arterial blood gas remains appropriately compensated with a respiratory alkalosis and normoxia. Careful observation is warranted, and the patient should be reassessed after therapy is initiated targeting the cause of the respiratory distress; if the patient does not improve, the risk-to-benefit ratio of intubation with mechanical ventilation should be carefully evaluated.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit for severe acute asthma. She is receiving supplemental oxygen as well as intravenous glucocorticoids and continuous inhaled albuterol therapy at maximum doses. Despite these measures, she continues to have severe increased work of breathing.
On examination, she is found to be awake and alert but is unable to speak in full sentences and has subcostal and intercostal retractions. On auscultation, there is faintly audible diffuse expiratory wheezing with little air movement bilaterally. She is maintaining an oxygen saturation of 95% on 80% fraction of inspired oxygen delivered via high-flow nasal cannula at 20 liters/minute. Her respiratory rate is 30 breaths per minute. Her blood pressure is 129/85 mm Hg.
Arterial blood gas testing reveals a pH of 7.40 (reference range, 7.35–7.45), a partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 35 mm Hg (32–48), and a partial pressure of oxygen of 85 mm Hg (83–108).
A chest radiograph obtained at presentation shows hyperinflation of the lungs without opacity.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain urgent CT of the brain
Increase high-flow nasal cannula to 30 liters/minute
Perform endotracheal intubation, and initiate mechanical ventilation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has respiratory distress and hypertension, there is no evidence to suggest these clinical findings are due to increased intracranial pressure. In addition, there is no evidence of altered mental status. Thus, a CT of the head is unlikely to provide any useful information, and transporting this unstable patient to radiology would pose an additional risk.

B) INCORRECT:

Heliox therapy, which is generally administered as a mixture of 20% to 30% oxygen and 70% to 80% helium, has been used in severe refractory asthma exacerbations. It increases laminar flow to improve gas exchange in obstructed lung units. It cannot be used if a patient requires a higher fraction of inspired oxygen than can be provided by the heliox mixture. Heliox therapy is not indicated in this patient who requires 80% fraction of inspired oxygen.

C) CORRECT:

An acute asthma exacerbation is classified as severe when the patient has any of the following functional parameters or clinical features: respiratory rate > 30, heart rate > 120, oxygen saturation < 90% on ambient air, PEF ≤ 50% of predicted value, dyspnea necessitating use of accessory muscles, tripod positioning, agitation, or inability to speak in complete sentences.

Pharmacotherapy should be maximized for severe asthma exacerbations and includes continuous inhaled albuterol (short-acting beta agonist), inhaled ipratropium bromide (short-acting muscarinic antagonist), and systemic glucocorticoids. Magnesium sulfate may also be given as a systemic bronchodilator but requires monitoring due to the risk of hypotension. Patients with severe asthma exacerbations also require urgent respiratory support in the form of supplemental oxygen therapy and should be monitored closely for signs of imminent respiratory failure, including drowsiness, confusion, and absence of wheezing (silent chest).

Key learning point: Patients with severe asthma exacerbation should be treated with supplemental oxygen, continuous inhaled albuterol, intravenous glucocorticoids, and inhaled ipratropium bromide. Intravenous magnesium sulfate should also be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is commonly used to deliver humidified high-flow oxygen therapy to children with respiratory distress, including those with severe asthma exacerbations. Although large studies are lacking, use of HFNC has demonstrated safety and patient tolerance in clinical practice. In this case, increasing flow through the HFNC is unlikely to improve the patient's condition. In addition, the delivery of inhalation medications like albuterol via HFNC may not be optimal at high flow rates, and care must be taken to not delay escalation in pharmacologic therapy when needed.

E) INCORRECT:

In a severe asthma exacerbation, patients should receive optimal pharmacotherapy and be monitored closely for impending respiratory failure. Drowsiness, confusion, and/or silent chest require ICU consultation and preparation for intubation. The decision to intubate in status asthmaticus is particularly difficult because tracheal manipulation can cause worsening bronchospasm, and mechanical ventilation can exacerbate hyperinflation leading to barotrauma. This patient is awake and alert, and some wheezing can still be heard on auscultation. If she does not improve with optimal pharmacotherapy, the patient may require intubation.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy with a history of moderate persistent asthma presents to the emergency department in severe respiratory distress. At home, he has been experiencing rhinorrhea and cough, followed by visible difficulty with breathing. His symptoms have not improved despite albuterol treatments every 4 hours.
He is currently afebrile, his heart rate is 128 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 42 breaths per minute, his blood pressure is 102/53 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 94% while he breathes ambient air. Air exchange is fair in all lung fields. Inspiration and expiration produce minimal wheezing.
Treatment with oxygen, bronchodilators, and systemic glucocorticoids is initiated. Twenty minutes later, the patient remains tachypneic with labored breathing.
Which one of the following additional findings would be most worrisome in this patient?

choices.text: He develops intercostal and supraclavicular retractions
His heart rate increases to 185 beats per minute
His respiratory rate increases to 62 breaths per minute
His chest examination no longer reveals wheezing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Worsening tachypnea, tachycardia, the presence of intercostal and supraclavicular retractions, and moderate hypoxemia (oxygen saturation percentage in the mid- to high 80s) would each indicate respiratory distress but would not be as worrisome as the absence of wheeze in a child who was initially wheezing on presentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Worsening tachypnea, tachycardia, the presence of intercostal and supraclavicular retractions, and moderate hypoxemia (oxygen saturation percentage in the mid- to high 80s) would each indicate respiratory distress but would not be as worrisome as the absence of wheeze in a child who was initially wheezing on presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

Worsening tachypnea, tachycardia, the presence of intercostal and supraclavicular retractions, and moderate hypoxemia (oxygen saturation percentage in the mid- to high 80s) would each indicate respiratory distress but would not be as worrisome as the absence of wheeze in a child who was initially wheezing on presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Worsening tachypnea, tachycardia, the presence of intercostal and supraclavicular retractions, and moderate hypoxemia (oxygen saturation percentage in the mid- to high 80s) would each indicate respiratory distress but would not be as worrisome as the absence of wheeze in a child who was initially wheezing on presentation.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with severe respiratory distress must be promptly distinguished from those with impending respiratory failure.

In patients with asthma, wheezing occurs because of airway obstruction. It is heard at the end of expiration when asthma is mild, and it occurs with inspiration and expiration when respiratory distress is more severe. The absence of wheezing in a child with respiratory distress suggests inadequate air exchange and potential respiratory failure. More wheezing would suggest that air exchange is improving and that the child is having a positive response to aggressive bronchodilator therapy.

This child was initially wheezing when he presented to the emergency department. The absence of wheeze either means that he has significantly improved and responded to therapy, or the disease process has progressed and airflow is too limited to produce a wheeze. Given that this patient is tachypneic with labored breathing, the latter is more likely and would signal worsening disease.

Key learning point: In a child with status asthmaticus, the absence of wheeze indicates extremely poor air movement, which may be a sign of impending respiratory failure.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath. He has a history of asthma. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. He is out of breath and unable to finish his sentences. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 23/min and labored, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows poor air movement bilaterally, no wheezing, and sternocleidomastoid muscle use. Oxygen is administered via a nonrebreather mask. He is given three doses of nebulized albuterol, inhaled ipratropium, and intravenous methylprednisolone. After 1 hour, the patient is confused and disoriented. Arterial blood gas analysis shows:


pH
7.34


Pco2
46 mm Hg


Po2
54 mm Hg


O2 saturation
87%


Assessing peak expiratory flow rate is not possible because the patient is unable to carry out the test due to shortness of breath. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient initially presented with a severe asthma exacerbation (difficulty speaking, accessory muscle use, labored breathing) that became life-threatening despite adequate medical treatment. He now presents with signs of imminent respiratory arrest, which warrants endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation. Treatment of severe to life-threatening asthma exacerbations includes oxygen therapy, nebulized SAMA and SABA, and systemic glucocorticoids. IV magnesium sulfate and inhaled glucocorticoid therapy can also be considered.

Most patients with acute asthma exacerbation initially present with respiratory alkalosis due to tachypnea. With worsening airway obstruction and increasing respiratory fatigue, Pco2 increases while pH decreases. Poor air movement combined with the absence of wheezing in this patient is also consistent with severe airway obstruction: wheezing is not heard because there is not enough air movement to generate it.
Image Description:

BP: blood pressure
HR: heart rate
ICS: inhaled corticosteroid
ICU: intensive care unit
IV: intravenous
O2: oxygen
PEF: peak expiratory flow
PO: per os
RR: respiratory rate
SABA: short-acting beta agonist
SAMA: short-acting muscarinic antagonist
SpO2: oxygen saturation

B) INCORRECT:

Theophylline is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor with antiinflammatory and bronchodilatory effects that can be used in maintenance therapy for COPD if no other bronchodilators are available. Theophylline is no longer routinely used in asthma because of its adverse cardiotoxic and neurotoxic effects.

C) INCORRECT:

Continuous albuterol nebulizer therapy can be used in patients with acute asthma exacerbation under specialist guidance, but there is insufficient data to recommend its routine use. Additionally, this patient has not responded to three doses of nebulized albuterol and now presents with signs of impending respiratory failure. Another step in management is more appropriate at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic therapy is often used in the treatment of acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease but is not routinely recommended in patients with acute asthma exacerbation without signs of infection (e.g., pneumonia).

E) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular epinephrine therapy is appropriate for patients with anaphylaxis, which can also cause dyspnea due to upper airway edema and bronchospasm. However, anaphylaxis is usually associated with other systemic symptoms such as urticaria, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, and/or angioedema. Epinephrine injections are not indicated for acute asthma exacerbation.
questions.hint: Silent chest, altered mental status, hypercapnia, and hypoxia suggest life-threatening asthma exacerbation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy with a history of moderate persistent asthma presents to the emergency department in severe respiratory distress. At home, he has been experiencing rhinorrhea and cough, followed by visible difficulty with breathing. His symptoms have not improved despite albuterol treatments every 4 hours. Pulse rate is 128/min, respiratory rate is 42/min, blood pressure is 102/53 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 94% while he breathes ambient air. Inspiration and expiration produce minimal wheezing. Treatment with oxygen, bronchodilators, and systemic glucocorticoids is initiated. Twenty minutes later, the patient remains tachypneic with labored breathing. Which of the following additional findings would be most worrisome in this patient?

His chest examination no longer reveals wheezing
His respiratory rate increases to 62 breaths per minute

C) CORRECT:

It is heard at the end of expiration when asthma is mild, and it occurs with inspiration and expiration when respiratory distress is more severe. The absence of wheezing in a child with respiratory distress suggests inadequate air exchange and potential respiratory failure. This child was initially wheezing when he presented to the emergency department.
